lessons.title: Rule of Thirds
lessons.content: The rule of thirds is a simple way to improve photo composition. Imagine breaking your image into 9 equal parts using two horizontal and two vertical lines. Placing your subject along these lines or at their intersections makes the photo more balanced and visually appealing.

lessons.title: Exposure
lessons.content: Exposure determines how light or dark your image appears. It is controlled by three main settings: aperture, shutter speed, and ISO.

lessons.title: Hue
lessons.content: Hue refers to the pure spectrum colors commonly referred to by color names - red, orange, yellow, blue, green violet - which appear in the hue circle or rainbow.

lessons.title: Saturation
lessons.content: Saturation refers to the intensity or purity of a color. A highly saturated color is vivid, while a less saturated color appears more muted or gray.
